The monks of the five Indian countries in the Western Regions maintain a slightly stricter and more elegant lifestyle. They may reside in monasteries,
temples, hermitages, or monks' gardens.
Every day they bathe the Buddha image, burn incense, and collect various famous flowers.
They make offerings by scattering them, pay homage, praise the Buddha,
and respectfully circumambulate with sincerity.
This is done every day.
They strive diligently until the end of their lives, without interruption.
Every morning, if they do not perform this offering, they vow not to eat.
All the countries far and near do this together, there is no place that does not do it.
This is what the monks always respectfully practice and uphold.
The only images that cannot be bathed are those made of earth, wood, and painted ones.
If they are made of gold, silver, precious stones, copper, zinc, or brass, such images can all be bathed regularly.
The fragrant water used for bathing the Buddha image the next morning
is soaked in various fragrances in the evening, finely ground, wrapped in silk, and soaked in water overnight.
However, all these fragrances are suitable for bathing the image.
One flavor of fragrant water, each in a separate bottle.
Also, do not mix many fragrances together in one place.
The bottles should be made of untouchable materials if possible.
That is to say, gold, silver, various treasures, iron, copper, lead, tin, white porcelain bottles that are not broken or damaged.
All must be polished and washed to make them bright and clean.
Arrange the names and numbers of the fragrant waters in order.
If one is poor and has none, one may take new, unused clean stone, earthenware, or wooden bottles to fulfill the task.
One must not use them for miscellaneous purposes, as they will then become defiled and untouchable.
After receiving and using them to store the fragrant water for bathing the image,
Those who practice this method should be most careful and attentive in protecting the rules of purity and untouchability.
All the vessels and objects for offerings should be understood according to this.
When it is time to bathe, sprinkle and sweep the hall and temple.
In a spacious and clean place, apply a large altar of clean cow dung, about one zhang in diameter.
Place a proclamation stand in the middle of the altar.
On top, place a large vessel.
In the middle, set up a small table to place the honored image, and place a bed beside it.
Cover it with an oil cloth, and arrange rows of various fragrant water bottles.
